author:
John Buffone
jbuffone@gametimepa.com @jdbuffone on Twitter
title: FOOTBALL: Manheim Central outlasts Cocalico, 21-15
text:
FOOTBALL: Manheim Central outlasts Cocalico, 21-15 
By John Buffone 
jbuffone@gametimepa.com @jdbuffone on Twitter Posted: 10/24/2015 12:25:23 AM EDT DENVER- Manheim Central head coach Dave Hahn is admittedly not a "fire and brimstone" kind of coach. 
But as his team trailed Section Two rival Cocalico 15-9 at halftime, he felt he needed to act a bit out of character to get his team on the right track. "There's a strong tradition here and these guys weren't living up to it in the first half," Hahn said. "So they needed to know about that strong tradition and know about the guys that played before them and how they played the game and if they want to be respected by those guys, they needed to step up and play." 
Taking their coaches words to heart, the Barons (6-2, 4-1) shut out the Eagles (4-4, 3-2) in the second half and came away with a crucial 21-15 victory. 
The game could not have started much worse for Manheim Central; losing a fumble on the first snap from scrimmage, which was recovered by the Eagles deep in Manheim territory. 
Cocalico fullback Hunter High would ultimately score on a three-yard touchdown run to give Cocalico an early 7-0 lead. 
As if that wasn't a bad enough way to begin a game, the Barons snapped the ball through the end zone for a safety while attempting a punt on their ensuing drive to extend the lead to 9-0. 
Manheim Central showed their first sign of life late in the first quarter when tailback Damon Camacho broke free on a 49-yard touchdown run. "I saw an opening and split two guys and just went up the field," Camacho said. 
Cocalico would answer back and extend their lead to 15-7 after a Dante Haines one-yard touchdown that capped off and 80 yard drive with 5:59 to play in the first half (PAT no good). 
Trying to regain some momentum, the Barons were marching down the field as time was waning in the second quarter. But the unlucky streak would continue after quarterback Kody Kegarise was picked off by Cocalico's DJ Fabiani inside the 5-yard-line with thirty-five seconds remaining. 
Then the tide began to turn. 
With 1:11 left in the third quarter, Barons' defensive back Drew Eshleman picked of Haines near midfield and returned it to the Eagles 29-yard-line. 
The Barons ultimately were able to punch it in with Camacho from the 1-yard-line to make it a two-point game. 
"In the first half, we were kind of soft and messing up on our keys. At halftime, coach gave us a talk about tradition and not letting our former players down and we picked it up," Camacho said. 
Then to add a little flair, the Barons pulled off a reverse pass to Kegarise to convert on their two-point attempt and tie the game. 
"I was a little bit scared to run it. We practiced it earlier in the year but we didn't practice it this week so I was a little scared to run it but I got a little encouragement that we should," Hahn said. "I told the kids that if we scored, we were going for two to get back in the game. I didn't want to be down 15-14 because then we'd start pressing." 
After another key defensive stop, the Barons offense finished the job with 4:57 remaining when Camacho took a handoff 20 yards to the house to put his team up 21-15 (conversion no good). 
Camacho led all rushers with 155 yards in addition to his three touchdowns. 
"Damon is a great athlete and a great player for us but if he doesn't have Sam Martin (TE), DaShuan Neville (OL), Adam Kline (OL), he's not as good." 
But it wouldn't be a Cocalico/Manheim Central game without a little drama at the end. 
Haines and the Eagles drove down the field in hopes of a game-winning touchdown/extra point and got inside the Barons 15-yard-line. 
However the Barons defense would make one more stand and forced an incomplete pass on fourth-and-five. 
"I thought our pass protection was OK but they just had everything covered," Eagle coach Dave Gingrich said "We thought we had a good play called and they covered it well." 
The win keeps the Barons within one game of first place Solanco (8-0, 5-0) with a Week 10 head-to-head matchup looming but must take care of Garden Spot next week. 
"It's important for us to get this win and to shake the loss from last week (L-S). We are battling a lot of injuries as were doubting ourselves. To get it is huge." 
Meanwhile, Cocalico drops to 3-2 in the Section Two race and has a date with the Golden Mules next week. 
"It should hurt. Nothing I'm going to say tonight is going to make it feel any better. I'd be disappointed if they weren't upset tonight," Gingrich said. 
"We all should be. I am. We'll wake up tomorrow and we'll get right back on it and start to get ready for Solanco."
